com.versant.trans
Class TransSession

java.lang.Object
  com.versant.fund.Constants
      com.versant.fund.MSessionVar
          com.versant.fund.Capi
              com.versant.fund.SynchronizedCapi
                  com.versant.fund.MSession
                      com.versant.fund.FundSession
                          com.versant.trans.TransSession
All Implemented Interfaces:
ClassBuilder, Session, SessionWithDatabase
Direct Known Subclasses:
ODMGSession
public class TransSession
extends FundSession

The VERSANT/Java Transparent Session class. This class can be directly instantiated when programming with applications that embody the VERSANT/Java Session concept, and its methods invoked to access the database functionality. Alternatively, application programs written to conform with the ODMG 2.0 Java Binding Specifications which implement the ODMG Database/Transaction model still have access to the VERSANT/Java Transparent Session. The VERSANT/Java Transparent Session presents VERSANT specific functionality that is not addressed in the ODMG 2.0 Java binding specifications.

SCHEMA_THROW_EXCEPTION_ALWAYS

public static final int SCHEMA_THROW_EXCEPTION_ALWAYS
a schema checking option to always throw a VSchemaException if there is any schema incompatibility between the database and the transparent Java class. This is the default value used.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

SCHEMA_ADD_DROP_ATTRIBUTES

public static final int SCHEMA_ADD_DROP_ATTRIBUTES
a schema checking option to automatically add attributes to the database schema if these are present in the transparent Java class, and, automatically delete attributes from the schema if these are not present in the transparent Java class. Other incompatibilities between the database and the transparent Java class would result in throwing a VSchemaException.

Method Detail

associateSession

public void associateSession(java.lang.Object object)
Changes the TransSession associated with a persistent object. Normally, each persistent Java object is associated with a single session until the object is garbage collected. However, the associateSession() method allows you to change the associated session. This is useful when using a pool of sessions that are allocated as necessary. The same persistent Java object may be involved with different sessions over its lifetime. The persistent object cannot be actively involved in a transaction when associateSession is called. If the object is active, VException 9817: EVJ_OBJECT_IS_ACTIVE will be thrown.

Parameters:
object - The persistent object to associate with a different Session.

autoDirtyUsesWeakRefs

public static void autoDirtyUsesWeakRefs(boolean weak)
Controls use of weak references. This method controls whether you should use "weak references" in a table that enables automatic dirtying with SCOs (Second Class Objects). Enabling weak references can free up memory in an application that accesses many SCOs within a single transaction. However, using weak references can hurt performance.

Note - This is a static method. For performance reasons, there is only one table used by all sessions for automatic dirtying. Changing the use of weak references applies to all sessions. This method should be called before any SCOs have been used.

The default is to use weak references.

Parameters:
weak - Set to true to use weak references, false otherwise.

checkAllTimestamps

public void checkAllTimestamps()
Check the timestamps of all dirty objects in the entire VERSANT front-end object cache.

Overrides:
checkAllTimestamps in class MSession
Throws:
- com.versant.fund.VException a run-time exception, if there are objects having different timestamps than timestamps of their database source objects. If VException.getErrno() returns OM_TR_INVALID_TS, then failed objects can be obtained using the VException.getTimestampFailedObjects() method. The objects which are not found in the database can be obtained using the VException.getNotFoundObjects() method.
See Also:
TransSession.checkTimestamps(Object[])

checkpointCommit

public void checkpointCommit()
Commits all persistent object modifications made within the session since the last checkpoint to the database. This method also retains all locks on those objects made prior to the call to checkpoint. A persistent object modification is an update of any field of an existing persistent object, or an update or creation of a new root object in the database.

If a persistent object modification results in a reference from an existing persistent object to a transient object, then the transient object is moved to the database and all references to it updated automatically. These actions can develop into a further set of references to transient objects and the commit process continues until there are no more references to transient objects from such modified persistent objects. This process is referred to as Transitive Persistence. Objects explicitly made persistent via the makePersistent() method call, or objects deleted via the deleteObject() method call would also get committed to the database.

Specified by:
checkpointCommit in interface Session
Overrides:
checkpointCommit in class MSession
See Also:
TransSession.commit(), TransSession.rollback()

checkpointCommit

public void checkpointCommit(java.lang.Object[] objects)
Performs a checkpoint commit on all new and dirty objects in the array. It keeps locks held on all objects and retains all objects in the VERSANT front-end object cache.

Parameters:
objects - The array of persistent objects on which to perform checkpoint.
See Also:
TransSession.commitAndRetain(Object[]), TransSession.rollbackAndRetain(Object[])

checkTimestamps

public void checkTimestamps(java.lang.Object[] objects)
Checks timestamps on the given array of objects. This method determines whether database source objects of the persistent objects in the argument have changed since copies were read into the VERSANT front-end object cache.

Parameters:
objects - the array containing persistent objects, which need their timestamps checked.
Throws:
VException - If there are objects whose timestamps are different from the timestamps of their database source objects. If VException.getErrno()returns error code OM_TR_INVALID_TS, then failed objects can be obtained using the VException.getFailedObjects() method. The objects which are not found in the database can be obtained using the VException.getNotFoundObjects() method.
See Also:
VException.getErrno(), VException.getFailedObjects(), TransSession.checkAllTimestamps()

clearJavaCache

public void clearJavaCache(boolean safe)
Clears the entire Java object cache except the objects in the dirty and deleted list. If safe is specified as true, then using a reference obtained before the call to clearJavaCache() results in the VException EVJ_OBJECT_WAS_CLEARED_FROM_JAVA_CACHE.

If safe is specified as false, then using a reference obtained before the call to clearJavaCache() can result in unpredictable behavior. Only use false when there is no further use for the persistent objects.

After calling this method, do not use references to any persistent objects associated with this session. All references must be retrieved through a query or findRoot operation.

Parameters:
safe - The safety flag.

See Also:
TransSession.clearJavaCacheObjects(java.lang.Object[], boolean)

clearJavaCacheObjects

public void clearJavaCacheObjects(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                                  boolean safe)
Clears the specified objects from the Java object cache.

Parameters:
objects - The persistent objects to be cleared from the Java object cache.

safe - The safety flag.

After calling this method, do not use references to any of the specified objects. See clearJavaCache().

This method is useful to remove objects from the cache that were referenced in previous transactions, and are no longer needed. Persistent objects that are not specified in the array are still valid and can be used normally.

See Also:
TransSession.clearJavaCache(boolean)

clearJavaCacheObjectsExcept

public void clearJavaCacheObjectsExcept(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                                        boolean safe)
Clears the entire Java object cache, except for those objects specified in the array.

Parameters:
objects - The persistent objects to be cleared from the Java object cache.

safe - The safety flag.

After calling this method, do not use references to any of the objects that are not in the given array. See clearJavaCache().

This method is useful to remove unnecessary objects from the cache, while retaining certain "root" objects.

Persistent objects that are not specified in the array are still valid and can be used normally.

See Also:
TransSession.clearJavaCache(boolean)

commit

public void commit()
Commits transaction.

This method commits all persistent object modifications within the session to their database(s) and releases any related locks held by this session.

A persistent object modification is an update of any field of an existing persistent object, or an update or creation of a new root object in the database.

If a persistent object modification results in a reference from an existing persistent object to a transient object, then the transient object is moved to the database and all references to it updated automatically.

This action can develop into a further set of references to transient objects. Furthermore, the commit process continues until there are no more references to transient objects from such modified persistent objects. (This process is referred to as Transitive Persistence.)

Objects explicitly made persistent through the makePersistent() method call, or those deleted through the deleteObject() method call would also become committed to the database.

Overrides:
commit in class MSession
See Also:
TransSession.rollback(), TransSession.commitAndCleanCod()

commitAndCleanCod

public void commitAndCleanCod()
Performs transaction commit and clears cache. This method commits all persistent object modifications made within the session, releases locks held on all objects, and releases all COD entries from the VERSANT front end object cache.

Overrides:
commitAndCleanCod in class MSession
See Also:
TransSession.commit(), TransSession.checkpointCommit(), TransSession.commitAndRetain(), TransSession.commitAndRetainSchema(), TransSession.rollback(), TransSession.rollbackAndRetain()

commitAndRetain

public void commitAndRetain()
Commits transaction and retains object cache. This method commits all persistent object modifications made within the session, release locks held on all objects, and retain persistent objects in the VERSANT front-end object cache.

Specified by:
commitAndRetain in interface Session
Overrides:
commitAndRetain in class MSession
See Also:
TransSession.commit(), TransSession.checkpointCommit(), TransSession.commitAndCleanCod(), TransSession.commitAndRetainSchema(), TransSession.rollback(), TransSession.rollbackAndRetain()

commitAndRetain

public void commitAndRetain(java.lang.Object[] objects)
Commits transaction and retains object cache.

Parameters:
objects - The array of persistent objects to be committed.

This method performs a regular commit of all new and dirty objects in the object array; keeps all objects in the VERSANT front-end object cache; and releases all object locks at the VERSANT back-end.

The dirty status of new and dirty objects not in the object array will remain unchanged. However, the deleted objects which are not present in the object array will get committed.

This method improves performance by specifically scanning the objects in the array, rather than all objects, during a commitAndRetain(). However, the state and status of new and dirty objects not in the array remains unchanged, and the new and dirty objects in program scope that are not in the array could be inconsistent with the state of those objects in the database.

For safety, before using this method, put all new, dirty, and deleted objects into the array.

See Also:
TransSession.checkpointCommit(), TransSession.rollbackAndRetain()

commitAndRetainSchema

public void commitAndRetainSchema()
Commits transaction and retains schema objects. This method commits all persistent object modifications made within the session, releases locks held on all objects, and retains persistent schema objects in the VERSANT front end object cache.

Overrides:
commitAndRetainSchema in class MSession
See Also:
TransSession.commit(), TransSession.checkpointCommit(), TransSession.commitAndCleanCod(), TransSession.commitAndRetain(), TransSession.rollback(), TransSession.rollbackAndRetain()

public void deleteRoot(java.lang.String rootName)

downgradeLocksTo

public void downgradeLocksTo(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                             int lockmode)
Downgrades locks on objects in an array to a specified lockmode.

Parameters:
objects - Array of persistent objects whose locks are to be downgraded.

lockmode - The lock mode to be set.

Alternatives for lockmode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK: Write lock -- A write lock prevents others from reading or updating the locked object. If a write lock is placed on a class object, the effect is to write lock both the class and all of its instances.
  • Constants.RIWLOCK Read/Intention-Write lock -- A read/intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It sets a read lock on instances of a class, and sets an intention write lock on the class object. This prevents others from updating locked instances or reading or updating the class object.
  • Constants.IWLOCK Intention-Write lock -- An intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It prevents others from reading or updating a class object.
  • Constants.ULOCK Update lock -- An update lock prevents others from updating the locked object and guarantees that you are the next to get a write lock on the updated locked object.
  • Constants.RLOCK Read lock -- If on an instance, a read lock allows others to read the locked object but not update it. If on a class object, a read lock allows others to read instances and the class object but not update instances or the class object.
  • Constants.IRLOCK Intention-Read lock -- An intention-read lock is only meaningful for a class object. It allows others to read the class object but not update it.
  • Constants.NOLOCK No lock -- Also called a snapshot lock or a null lock. A no lock provides no concurrency guarantees.
If size of specified object array is zero and specified lockmode is NOLOCK then this function will release all the locks of the active transaction.

Throws:
VException - If there are objects that fail to have their locks downgraded.

    Failed objects that can be obtained using the VException.getFailedObjects () method.

See Also:
VException.getFailedObjects(), HandleVector.downgradeLocksTo(int)

endSession

public void endSession()
Ends this session, performs a short commit, terminates the current database session and closes associated communication channels to the database server.

endSession always commits the changes made within the context of the current transaction to the database. If this is undesirable then the changes made in the current transaction have to be rolled back before calling endSession.

To end a session, the current thread must be the only thread that is attached to the session.

Overrides:
endSession in class FundSession
Throws:
VException.EVJ_CANNOT_END_SESSION_INUSE - If the session is still in use.

VException.EVJ_CANNOT_END_UNATTACHED_SESSION - If the session is not attached to this thread.

See Also:
FundSession.endSession(int), MSession.endSession(String), MSession.endSession(String, int)

rootName - The name used to root an object in the database. Names provide one way to navigate and retrieve objects from a database.

                                 java.lang.String dbName)

getClosure

public java.lang.Object[] getClosure(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                                     java.lang.String dbName,
                                     int levels,
                                     boolean toPin,
                                     int lockmode)
Returns an object array containing both the starting-point objects and their closure.

Parameters:
objects - The object array that contains persistent objects used as starting-point objects to evaluate.
dbName - The name of database in which to perform a closure.
levels - The number of levels of links to traverse starting from the objects found by the predicate.
  • Specify 0 to return only the found objects.
  • Specify -1 to return all objects linked directly or indirectly to the found objects.
  • Specify a positive number to indicate the number of levels of links to follow beginning with the found objects. For example, specify 1 to return objects that are the direct target of links in the objects found by the predicate, and specify 2 also to return objects that are the target of links in the first level of linked objects.
toPin - Returned objects are to be pinned in VERSANT front-end object cache or not.

    Note: If objects are pinned, you need to later manually unpin the objects using com.versant.fund.Handle.unpinObject() or release them by ending the transaction.

lockmode - The lock mode to be used.

    Alternatives for lockmode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK: Write lock -- A write lock prevents others from reading or updating the locked object. If a write lock is placed on a class object, the effect is to write lock both the class and all of its instances.
  • Constants.RIWLOCK Read/Intention-Write lock -- A read/intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It sets a read lock on instances of a class, and sets an intention write lock on the class object. This prevents others from updating locked instances or reading or updating the class object.
  • Constants.IWLOCK Intention-Write lock -- An intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It prevents others from reading or updating a class object.
  • Constants.ULOCK Update lock -- An update lock prevents others from updating the locked object and guarantees that you are the next to get a write lock on the updated locked object.
  • Constants.RLOCK Read lock -- If on an instance, a read lock allows others to read the locked object but not update it. If on a class object, a read lock allows others to read instances and the class object but not update instances or the class object.
  • Constants.IRLOCK Intention-Read lock -- An intention-read lock is only meaningful for a class object. It allows others to read the class object but not update it.
  • Constants.NOLOCK No lock -- Also called a snapshot lock or a null lock. A no lock provides no concurrency guarantees.
If size of specified object array is zero and specified lockmode is NOLOCK then this function will release all the locks of the active transaction.

If you specify the lock mode to be RLOCK or IRLOCK, and have used FundSession.setThreadOptions (com.versant.fund.Constants.DROP_RLOCK), then the database server will drop the RLOCK or IRLOCK after the closure evaluation.

Using persistent objects in the array as starting-point objects, this method:

Evaluates objects reachable from the starting-point objects for the specified number of levels in the named database.

Returns an object array to contain both the starting-point objects and their referenced objects.

The returned objects are placed in VERSANT front end object cache, are optionally pinned, and have either a default lock or a specified lock.

See Also:
FundSession.setThreadOptions(int), Handle.unpinObject()

getDefaultDatabase

public java.lang.String getDefaultDatabase()
Get default database name. The default database is the database where newly created objects go. It is used in the Transparent binding alone. In the Fundamental binding, you have to explicitly specify a database name with every operation.

Returns:
default database name

getSessionClassLoader

public java.lang.ClassLoader getSessionClassLoader()
Returns the currently active "session class loader." If there is no session class loader (other than the system class loader), then returns null. The session class loader is set by the setSessionClassLoader() method.

Returns:
ClassLoader set for this session

getOidAsLong

public static long getOidAsLong(java.lang.Object object)
Returns the LOID associated with the given object. The LOID is returned as an 8-byte integer, which is the most efficient representation. The given object can be persistent or transient; if the object is transient and does not have an associated LOID, then this method returns 0.

Returns:
LOID as long value

getOidAsString

public static java.lang.String getOidAsString(java.lang.Object object)
Returns the LOID associated with the given object. The LOID is returned as a string, using the human-readable "dotted decimal" representation. The given object can be persistent or transient; if the object is transient and does not have an associated LOID, then this method returns null.

Returns:
LOID as String

setOid

public static void setOid(java.lang.Object object,
                          long oid)
This method associates the given LOID with a transient object. After calling setOid(), the object is still transient; however, the setPersistentState() method can be used to make the object persistent. The LOID is given in its 8-byte integer representation, which can be obtained using the getOidAsLong() method. If the given LOID is 0, then the object will not have an LOID associated with it.

You cannot change the LOID of an object that is already persistent. If the given object is not transient, then the VException 9816: EVJ_NOT_A_TRANSIENT_INSTANCE is thrown.

Parameters:
object - the transient object
oid - the new loid as long
Throws:
EVJ_NOT_A_TRANSIENT_INSTANCE

Parameters:
loid - the loid as long to be checked

setOid

public static void setOid(java.lang.Object object,
                          java.lang.String oid)
This method associates the given LOID with a transient object. After calling setOid(), the object is still transient; however, the setPersistentState() method can be used to make the object persistent. The LOID is given in its human-readable string representation, which can be obtained using the getOidAsString() method. If the given LOID is null (or "0.0.0"), then the object will not have an LOID associated with it.

You cannot change the LOID of an object that is already persistent. If the given object is not transient, then the VException 9816: EVJ_NOT_A_TRANSIENT_INSTANCE is thrown.

Parameters:
object - the transient object
oid - the new loid as String
Throws:
EVJ_NOT_A_TRANSIENT_INSTANCE - if object is not transient

groupDeleteObjects

public void groupDeleteObjects(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                               java.lang.String dbName)
Deletes persistent objects in an array from a specified database.

In an optimistic locking session, before deleting an object from its database, this function will compare the time stamp for each object in the objects parameter with the time stamp for the corresponding database object.

If the time stamp for your copy object is not equal to the time stamp for the database counterpart, then it fails the time stamp validation, which means that the database object has been updated since the time you read in your copy.

This kind of failure to delete can occur only in an optimistic locking session.

Parameters:
objects - An array of persistent objects to be deleted.
dbName - The name of the database that contains objects to be deleted.

Deletions of the objects in the database are complete only after they are committed.

Throws:
VException - If the object does not belong to a Persistent class category, or, if an attempt is made to delete the object when it has become persistent in the database.

groupReadObjects

public void groupReadObjects(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                             java.lang.String dbName,
                             int option,
                             int lockmode)
Group reads an array of objects.

Parameters:
objects - The array that contains persistent objects to be group read.
dbName - The name of the database from which to fetch objects.

option - Method options.

lockmode - The lock mode to be used in reading objects.

Alternatives for the option parameter are:

  • 0 - Do not pin objects or release their locks.
  • Constants.PIN_OBJECTS - Pin objects in the VERSANT front-end object cache.
      • Note: you need to later manually unpin them using com.versant.fund.Handle.unpinObject() or release them by ending the transaction.
  • Constants.DOWNGRADE_LOCKS - Release locks after objects have been fetched.
  • Constants.PIN_OBJECTS | Constants.DOWNGRADE_LOCKS - Pin and unlock objects.
Alternatives for lockmode are:

  • Constants.WLOCK: Write lock -- A write lock prevents others from reading or updating the locked object. If a write lock is placed on a class object, the effect is to write lock both the class and all of its instances.
  • Constants.RIWLOCK Read/Intention-Write lock -- A read/intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It sets a read lock on instances of a class, and sets an intention write lock on the class object. This prevents others from updating locked instances or reading or updating the class object.
  • Constants.IWLOCK Intention-Write lock -- An intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It prevents others from reading or updating a class object.
  • Constants.ULOCK Update lock -- An update lock prevents others from updating the locked object and guarantees that you are the next to get a write lock on the updated locked object.
  • Constants.RLOCK Read lock -- If on an instance, a read lock allows others to read the locked object but not update it. If on a class object, a read lock allows others to read instances and the class object but not update instances or the class object.
  • Constants.IRLOCK Intention-Read lock -- An intention-read lock is only meaningful for a class object. It allows others to read the class object but not update it.
  • Constants.NOLOCK No lock -- Also called a snapshot lock or a null lock. A no lock provides no concurrency guarantees. If size of specified object array is zero and specified lockmode is NOLOCK then this function will release all the locks of the active transaction.

    If you specify the lock mode to be RLOCK or IRLOCK, and have used FundSession.setThreadOptions (com.versant.fund.Constants.DROP_RLOCK), then the database server will drop the RLOCK or IRLOCK after the read operation.

    This method fetches persistent objects in the array into the VERSANT front end object cache, optionally pins the objects in the front end cache, and optionally places specified locks on the objects.

    See Also:
    Handle.unpinObject()

    • groupWriteObjects

    public void groupWriteObjects(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                              int option)
    Group writes an array of objects.

    Parameters:
    objects - An array of persistent objects to be written to the database.
    option - Method options Alternatives for the option parameter are:

  • 0 - Null option.
  • Constants.FREE_OBJECTS - Release objects in the array from the VERSANT front-end object cache.
  • Constants.CLEAN_CODS - Release the cached object descriptors of objects in the array from the VERSANT front-end object cache.

    • This method:

    writes the persistent objects in the array to their source database,

    marks the objects as clean, and optionally releases the objects from the VERSANT front end object cache, or

    releases their cached object descriptors from the VERSANT front-end object cache.

    All objects must be from the same database.

    This method should be used only for memory management purposes, since objects written with this method are still part of the current transaction and subject to a rollback.

    If objects are written with this method and their locks are then downgraded, there will be unpredictable results when the transaction rolls back.

    To save changes and release locks, commit the transaction instead of using this method.

    groupWriteClustered

    public void groupWriteClustered(java.lang.String dbname,
                                java.lang.Object parent_object,
                                java.lang.Object[] objects,
                                int option)
    Writes a group of objects to a database and places the objects near an existing parent object. The parent object should belong to the same class as the child objects. If the parent object is newly created, you must explicitly write it out before using it in a groupWriteClustered() operation. VERSANT attempts to place the child objects on the same page as the parent object. If the page does not have enough space, some objects will be written to a new page.

    Parameters:
    dbname - The database in which the objects are contained.
    parent_object - The parent object, which is used to determine a storage location for the objects that are written.
    objects - The array of persistent objects to be written to database.
    option - The valid options are:

  • 0 - No options specified.
  • Constants.FREE_OBJECTS - Release objects in the array from the VERSANT front-end object cache.
  • Constants.CLEAN_CODS - Release the cached object descriptors of objects in the array from the VERSANT front-end object cache.

    • groupWriteIsolated

    public void groupWriteIsolated(java.lang.String dbname,
                               java.lang.Object[] objects,
                               int option)
    Writes a group of objects to a database and isolate the objects on their own page. A group write isolated operation works like a normal group write, but it suggests that the database isolate the given objects on their own page. This means
    • VERSANT always uses a new page to store each object.
    • Each such new page will not be used for storing objects except through a "group write clustered" operation in which the parent object is the object on the page.

    Parameters:
    dbname - The database in which the objects are contained.
    objects - array of persistent objects to be written to database
    option - valid options include:

      0 - No options specified.
      Constants.FREE_OBJECTS - Release objects in the array from the VERSANT front-end object cache.
      Constants.CLEAN_CODS - Release the cached object descriptors of objects in the array from the VERSANT front-end object cache.

    makeTransient

    public void makeTransient(java.lang.Object object)
    Makes a persistent capable object into a transient instance.

    Parameters:
    object - The persistent capable object to remove from any association with the session.

    After makeTransient() is invoked, the Persistent Capable object loses its association with the session and the database. It does, however, retain its LOID. This allows the object to be re-associated with a session and a database at a later time using the setPersistentState() method.

    The object will be read from the database before being made transient. This method is equivalent to makeTransient(obj,true).

    Note that makeTransient() can not be used for Persistent Always objects.

    makeTransientWithoutRelease

    public static void makeTransientWithoutRelease(java.lang.Object object)

    makeTransient

    public void makeTransient(java.lang.Object object,
                          boolean read)
    Makes a persistent capable object into a transient instance.

    Parameters:
    object - The persistent object to remove from any association with the session.
    read - If set to true, the object will first be read object from database.

    After makeTransient() is invoked, the Persistent Capable object loses its association with the session and the database. It does, however, retain its LOID. This allows the object to be re-associated with a session and a database at a later time using the setPersistentState() method.

    If the read parameter is true, the object will be read from the database before being made transient; otherwise, the object will retain whatever values (possibly null or garbage) are in its fields when makeTransient() is called.

    Note that makeTransient() can not be used for Persistent Always objects.

    makeRoot

    public void makeRoot(java.lang.String rootName,
                     java.lang.Object obj)
    Relates a previously transient object (a category which can be stored persistently) to a unique name in the session database and makes the object persistent.

    Parameters:
    rootName - The name used to root an object in the database.
    obj - The object being bound to a root name in the database. The same object could be bound to more than one name in the database. Names provide one way to navigate and retrieve objects from a database.

    obj - The object being bound to a root name in the database. The same object could be bound to more than one name in the given database. Names provide one way to navigate and retrieve objects from a database.

    dbName - The database associated with this session.

    Throws:
    com.versant.fund.VException, - a run-time exception, if the object does not belong to a Persistent class category.

    refreshObjects

    public void refreshObjects(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                           java.lang.String dbName,
                           int lockmode)
    Update the persistent objects in the given array with the current state of the objects in the named database, and place the specified lock on these objects.

    Parameters:
    objects - The object array containing persistent objects that are to be refreshed.

    dbName - The name of the database where objects reside.

    lockmode - The lock mode to be used.

    Alternatives for lockmode are:

    • Constants.WLOCK: Write lock -- A write lock prevents others from reading or updating the locked object. If a write lock is placed on a class object, the effect is to write lock both the class and all of its instances.
    • Constants.RIWLOCK Read/Intention-Write lock -- A read/intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It sets a read lock on instances of a class, and sets an intention write lock on the class object. This prevents others from updating locked instances or reading or updating the class object.
    • Constants.IWLOCK Intention-Write lock -- An intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It prevents others from reading or updating a class object.
    • Constants.ULOCK Update lock -- An update lock prevents others from updating the locked object and guarantees that you are the next to get a write lock on the updated locked object.
    • Constants.RLOCK Read lock -- If on an instance, a read lock allows others to read the locked object but not update it. If on a class object, a read lock allows others to read instances and the class object but not update instances or the class object.
    • Constants.IRLOCK Intention-Read lock -- An intention-read lock is only meaningful for a class object. It allows others to read the class object but not update it.
    • Constants.NOLOCK No lock -- Also called a snapshot lock or a null lock. A no lock provides no concurrency guarantees.
    If you specify the lockmode to be RLOCK or IRLOCK, and have used FundSession.setThreadOptions (com.versant.fund.Constants.DROP_RLOCK), then the database server will drop the RLOCK or IRLOCK after sending the refreshed objects.

    All objects must come from the same database.

    See Also:
    FundSession.setThreadOptions(int)

    refreshObjectsExcept

    public void refreshObjectsExcept(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                                 java.lang.String dbName,
                                 int lockmode)
    Update all the persistent objects in the cache that are not given in the array with the current state of the objects in the named database, and place the specified lock on these objects.

    Parameters:

    dbName - The name of the database where objects reside.

    lockmode - The lock mode to be used.

    Alternatives for lockmode are:

    • Constants.WLOCK: Write lock -- A write lock prevents others from reading or updating the locked object. If a write lock is placed on a class object, the effect is to write lock both the class and all of its instances.
    • Constants.RIWLOCK Read/Intention-Write lock -- A read/intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It sets a read lock on instances of a class, and sets an intention write lock on the class object. This prevents others from updating locked instances or reading or updating the class object.
    • Constants.IWLOCK Intention-Write lock -- An intention-write lock is only meaningful for a class object. It prevents others from reading or updating a class object.
    • Constants.ULOCK Update lock -- An update lock prevents others from updating the locked object and guarantees that you are the next to get a write lock on the updated locked object.
    • Constants.RLOCK Read lock -- If on an instance, a read lock allows others to read the locked object but not update it. If on a class object, a read lock allows others to read instances and the class object but not update instances or the class object.
    • Constants.IRLOCK Intention-Read lock -- An intention-read lock is only meaningful for a class object. It allows others to read the class object but not update it.
    • Constants.NOLOCK No lock -- Also called a snapshot lock or a null lock. A no lock provides no concurrency guarantees.
    If you specify the lockmode to be RLOCK or IRLOCK, and have used FundSession.setThreadOptions (com.versant.fund.Constants.DROP_RLOCK), then the database server will drop the RLOCK or IRLOCK after sending the refreshed objects.

    All objects must come from the same database.

    releaseObjects

    public void releaseObjects(java.lang.Object[] objects)
    Releases an array of objects from the Java cache.

    Parameters:
    objects - The array of objects to be released.

    The object array should not contain nulls.

    Subsequent access to any object that is released will cause the attributes for the object to be fetched from the database.

    See Also:
    TransSession.releaseObjectsExcept(java.lang.Object[]), TransSession.releaseObject(java.lang.Object)

    releaseObjectsExcept

    public void releaseObjectsExcept(java.lang.Object[] objects)
    Releases all objects that are not in the given array from the Java cache.

    Parameters:
    objects - The array of objects that should not be released.

    The object array should not contain nulls.

    Subsequent access to any object that is released will cause the attributes for the object to be fetched from the database.

    See Also:
    TransSession.releaseObject(java.lang.Object)

    rollback

    public void rollback()
    Rolls back the session. This method rolls back the session by abandoning all persistent object modifications and releases any associated database locks.

    Objects explicitly made persistent via the makePersistent() method call, or those deleted via the deleteObject() method call will not affect the database state.

    Overrides:
    rollback in class MSession
    See Also:
    TransSession.commit()

    rollbackAndRetain

    public void rollbackAndRetain()
    Rolls back the session and retains the cache. This method:

    Performs a rollback of the session by abandoning all persistent object modifications.

    Releases any associated database locks.

    Retains objects in the VERSANT front end object cache.

    Specified by:
    rollbackAndRetain in interface Session
    Overrides:
    rollbackAndRetain in class MSession
    See Also:
    TransSession.rollback()

    rollbackAndRetain

    public void rollbackAndRetain(java.lang.Object[] objs)
    Rolls back the session and retain the cache.

    Parameters:
    objs - An object array.

    This method:

    Rolls back all new and dirty objects in object array.

    Releases all new and dirty objects in the object array from the VERSANT front-end object cache.

    Keeps all clean objects in the VERSANT cache.

    Retains remaining objects in the VERSANT front end object cache.

    Releases locks on all objects.

    Drops all changes made in database.

    This method improves performance by specifically scanning the objects in the array, rather than all objects, during a rollback. However, the state and status of new and dirty objects not in the array remains unchanged, and the new and dirty objects in program scope not in the array will not be consistent with the state of those objects in the database.

    To be safe, before using this method, put all new and dirty objects into the array.

    Objects explicitly made persistent through the makePersistent() method call, or those deleted through the deleteObject() method call will not affect the database state.

    See Also:
    TransSession.checkpointCommit(), TransSession.commitAndRetain()

    savepoint

    This is a placeholder method.

    Invoking this method throws a run-time exception.

    select

    public VEnumeration select(java.lang.Class c,
                           Predicate p,
                           java.lang.String dbName,
                           int option,
                           int level,
                           int classLockMode,
                           int instLockMode)
    Selects object references from the named database for the given predicate and returns a VEnumeration.

    Parameters:
    c - The class object to select in the database.
    p - The Predicate instance used in the query.

    dbName - The database name used to select objects.

    option - The select option.

    Alternative for option are:

    • Contants.TOPIN - Pin fetched objects in memory.

      • To fetch objects, you must specify the Constants.FETCH_LAST option. The default is to not pin fetched objects. If you pin objects, you must later manually unpin them with unpinobj () or release them with a commit, rollback, or undosavepoint. The default is to return links but not bring the found objects into memory.

    • Contants.FLUSH_NONE - Do not flush the object cache before performing the query.

      • You cannot use both Constants.FLUSH_NONE and Constants.FLUSH_ALL. See notes for Constants.FLUSH_ALL for an explanation.

    • Contants.FLUSH_ALL - Flush the object cache before performing the query.

      • The default is to flush the dirty objects of the specified class before performing the query.

      You cannot use both Constants.FLUSH_NONE and Constants.FLUSH_ALL.

      Because queries are performed in the server process on the query database, normally you should flush the object cache so that the query evaluates and returns the latest state of each object. However, since flushing an object marks it as clean, if you modify an object again after the query you must again mark it dirty.

    • Contants.FETCH_LAST -- Fetch objects that satisfy the query.

      • By default, objects that satisfy a query are not fetched from their database and placed in memory.

      If you have specified levels as other than zero, this option will fetch objects to the last level specified. By default objects of last level are not fetched. Objects of intermediate levels are always fetched.

    • Contants.SELECT_DEEP - Evaluate target class and it's subclasses.

      • This is the default option for queries where the from target is a class.

    level - The number of levels of links to traverse starting from the objects found by the predicate.

    • Specify 0 to return only the found objects.
    • Specify -1 to return all objects linked directly or indirectly to the found objects.
    • Specify a positive number to indicate the number of levels of links to follow beginning with the found objects.

      For example, specify 1 to return objects that are the direct target of links in the objects found by the predicate, and specify 2 also to return objects that are the target of links in the first level of linked objects.

    classLockMode - The short lock to be placed on the class object. To avoid unintentional side affects, you should normally only specify one of the following:

    • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
    • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
    • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock

    instLockMode - The lock to be placed on returned instances.

    Alternatives for lock modes are:

    • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
    • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
    • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
    • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
    • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
    • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
    • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock
    A null predicate returns all the instances of the class in the database.

    See Also:
    VEnumeration, Predicate

    selectWithCursor

    public VEnumeration selectWithCursor(java.lang.Class c,
                                     Predicate p,
                                     int batchSize)
    Selects references to objects in the session database for the given predicate, returning a VEnumeration, using a database cursor. A null predicate returns all the instances of the class in the database. A cursor select returns a VEnumeration just as the regular select method does. In addition, it creates a cursor that fetches objects from the database one batch at a time, where the batch size is according to the supplied argument.

    In iterating through the VEnumeration using the nextElement () method, the cursor is transparently advanced to fetch the next batch of objects.

    By fetching batches of object reference at a time using a cursor rather than all the objects at once, a cursor query reduces lock contention on the fetched objects and lessens memory usage.

    When you finish using a cursor you must invalidate it to release it. This can be done by invoking the invalidateCursor() method on the VEnumeration instance.

    Parameters:
    c - The class being selected from in the database.
    p - The Predicate instance used in the query.
    batchSize - The size of the batch fetched when the cursor is advanced.

    selectWithCursor

    public VEnumeration selectWithCursor(java.lang.Class c,
                                     Predicate p,
                                     java.lang.String dbName,
                                     int batchSize)
    Selects references to objects in the session database for the given predicate, returning a VEnumeration, using a database cursor. A null predicate returns all the instances of the class in the database. A cursor select returns a VEnumeration just as the regular select method does. In addition, it creates a cursor that fetches objects from the database one batch at a time, where the batch size is according to the supplied argument.

    In iterating through the VEnumeration using the nextElement () method, the cursor is transparently advanced to fetch the next batch of objects.

    By fetching batches of object at a time using a cursor rather than all the objects at once, a cursor query reduces lock contention on the fetched objects and lessens memory usage.

    When you finish using a cursor you must invalidate it to release it. This can be done by invoking the invalidateCursor() method on the VEnumeration instance.

    Parameters:
    c - The class being selected from in the database.
    p - The Predicate instance used in the query.
    dbName - The name of the database used to select objects from.
    batchSize - The size of the batch fetched when the cursor is advanced.

    setLoid

    public void setLoid(java.lang.Object object,
                    long loid)
    Associates a persistent capable Java object with the given loid. The object must be transient; if the object has already been made persistent, the VException 9816: EVJ_NOT_A_TRANSIENT_INSTANCE will be thrown. An object of the given loid must already exist in the database, and must be of the same class as the Java object.

    setSchemaOption

    public void setSchemaOption(int opt)
    Sets the schema checking option for this session.

    Parameters:
    opt - The schema checking option to be used in this session.

    The schema checking option can be one of the following:

    • SCHEMA_ADD_DROP_ATTRIBUTES

      A schema checking option to automatically add attributes to the database schema if these are present in the transparent Java class and, automatically delete attributes from the schema if these are not present in the transparent Java class.

    • SCHEMA_FORCE_DROP_DATABASE

      A schema checking option to drop the class in the database and redefine its schema if there is an incompatibility between the database and the transparent Java class.

    • SCHEMA_THROW_EXCEPTION_ALWAYS

      A schema checking option to always throw a VSchemaException if there is any schema incompatibility between the database and the transparent Java class.

    All of these options are static variables of this class.

    setSessionClassLoader

    public void setSessionClassLoader(java.lang.ClassLoader classloader)
    Sets the "session class loader." The session class loader is used to load persistent classes (and related classes such as the "pickler"). The session class loader should be the same as the class loader used to load the application classes. For example, if the application runs within an applet, the session class loader should be set to the applet's "network class loader."

    The setSessionClassLoader() method should only be called when there are no objects already cached in the session. Therefore, this method should only be used immediately after the session is constructed, or after calling the clearJavaCache() method. Otherwise, errors such as ClassCastException may result.

    Parameters:
    classloader - the classloader to be used to load the users persistent classes.

    zapObjects

    public void zapObjects(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                       boolean release)
    Removes the COD entries from the VERSANT front-end cache for all the persistent objects in the array.

    Releases the objects from memory and makes their cached object descriptors in the underlying c cache available for re-use. Because this method invalidates object handles to the underlying c cache, it should be used with care.

    • You should never release the cached object descriptor for a class object.
    • You should never release the cached object descriptor for an object marked as dirty.
    • You should never release the cached object descriptor for an object, which is the target of a handle in an object, marked as dirty.
    • The array should not contain any null values or any non-persistent objects
    If you zap the cached object descriptor for a dirty object you get the error OM_DB_NOT_FOUND or OM_COD_ALREADY_FREED during commit or flushing. In this case VERSANT is not able to find the cached object descriptor for the target object.

    However, if you continue in the same transaction after using this function, VERSANT may reuse the previously zapped cached object descriptor, in which case you will potentially corrupt the handle without getting an error.

    The objects can still be accessed after being zapped. However, any handles obtained from the zapped objects using the TransSession.objectToHandle() method will no longer be valid.

    Clearing the cached object descriptor table does not affect the database state of an object.

    Releasing cached object descriptors frees space in the cached object descriptor table for reuse, which is useful if you need to reclaim space in the application process heap during a session that references a very large number (say, a million or more) of objects.

    When you run out of space in the application process heap, you see error number 4161, OM_HEAP_NOMEM, "Out of front-end heap memory". The initial size of the application process heap is determined by the heap_size parameter in the application process parameter file, but it expands dynamically as needed. Thus, this error message can also mean that the objects themselves are taking too much space, so first try unpinning the objects and only use zapcods() as a last resort.

    Parameters:
    objects - The array of persistent objects to be zapped.

    release

      If this parameter is true, then the zapped objects will also be released from the Java object cache.

    See Also:
    HandleVector.zapObjects(), TransSession.releaseObjects(java.lang.Object[])

    zapObjectsExcept

    public void zapObjectsExcept(java.lang.Object[] objects,
                             boolean release)
    Removes the COD entries from the VERSANT from front-end cache for any persistent objects that are not in the given array.

    Releases the objects from memory and makes their cached object descriptors in the underlying c cache available for re-use. Because this method invalidates object handles to the underlying c cache, it should be used with care.

    • You should never release the cached object descriptor for an object marked as dirty.
    • You should never release the cached object descriptor for an object, which is the target of a handle in an object, marked as dirty.
    • The array should not contain any null values or any non-persistent objects
    If you zap the cached object descriptor for a dirty object you get the error OM_DB_NOT_FOUND or OM_COD_ALREADY_FREED during commit or flushing, because VERSANT is not able to find the cached object descriptor for the target object. However, if you continue in the same transaction after using this function, VERSANT may reuse the previously zapped cached object descriptor, in which case you will potentially corrupt the handle without getting an error.

    The objects can still be accessed after being zapped. However, any handles obtained from the zapped objects using the TransSession.objectToHandle() method will no longer be valid.

    Releasing cached object descriptors frees space in the cached object descriptor table for reuse, which is useful if you need to reclaim space in the application process heap during a session that references a very large number (say, a million or more) of objects.

    When you run out of space in the application process heap, you see error number 4161, OM_HEAP_NOMEM, "Out of front-end heap memory". The initial size of the application process heap is determined by the heap_size parameter in the application process parameter file, but it expands dynamically as needed. Thus, this error message can also mean that the objects themselves are taking too much space, so first try unpinning the objects and only use zapcods() as a last resort.

    Clearing the cached object descriptor table does not affect the database state of an object.

    Parameters:
    objects - The array of objects that will not be zapped. This array should not contain any null values.

    release

      If this parameter is true, then the zapped objects will also be released from the Java object cache.

    See Also:
    HandleVector.zapObjects(), TransSession.releaseObjects(java.lang.Object[])

    setPersistentState

    public void setPersistentState(java.lang.Object obj,
                               java.lang.String dbName,
                               int state)
    Associates a transient instance of a Persistent Capable object with a session and a database.

    Parameters:
    obj - The transient persistent capable object to make persistent.

    dbName - The database in which the object is stored.

    state - The persistent object state that the object will acquire.

    This method allows a transient object to be incorporated into the Java cache, by associating it with a session and a database. The given transient object must have an associated LOID. A transient object can acquire a LOID in two ways:

    A persistent object can become transient, retaining its persistent identity. This can occur explicitly through the makeTransient() method, or implicitly by serializing and deserializing a persistent object.

    The setOid() method can be used to explicitly associate a LOID with a transient object.

    The setPersistentState() method allows you to control which state the persistent object will attain in the Java cache. The possible values for the state parameter are:

    Constants.DIRTY_STATE - Immediately mark the object as "dirty." Therefore the object will be written to the database with other dirty objects (usually when the transaction commits). A WLOCK will be placed on the object. An object with the given LOID must already exist in the database.

    Constants.CLEAN_STATE - The object becomes persistent in the "clean" state. A default lock (typically RLOCK) will be placed on the object. An object with the given LOID must already exist in the database.

    Constants.INACTIVE_STATE - The object becomes persistent in the "inactive" state. Therefore any values stored in the fields of the transient object will be discarded after setPersistentState() is called, and any access to the object will cause its fields to be fetched from the database. An object with the given LOID should already exist in the database.

    Constants.NEW_STATE - The object will be marked as "new," so that a new object with the given LOID will be created in the specified database. Normally, new objects are created with the makePersistent() method (or through transitive persistence). The NEW_STATE option allows direct control of the LOIDs assigned to new objects. An object with the given LOID must not already exist in the database.

    Note that setPersistentState() is an advanced method that provides direct control of the placement of objects in the Java cache, and should be used with appropriate caution.

    Only one object per session can be associated with a particular LOID. If an object with the given LOID already exists in the cache when setPersistentState() is called, then the new object will replace the old one.

    The object must be transient; if the object has already been made persistent, the VException 9816: EVJ_NOT_A_TRANSIENT_INSTANCE will be thrown.

    See Also:
    and getOid

    setPersistentState

    public void setPersistentState(java.lang.Object obj,
                               java.lang.String dbName,
                               int state,
                               int lockmode)
    Associates a transient instance of a Persistent Capable object with a session and a database.

    Parameters:
    obj - The transient persistent capable object to make persistent.

    dbName - The database in which the object is stored.

    state - The persistent object state that the object will acquire.

    lockmode - the lockmode to be placed on the object

    This method allows a transient object to be incorporated into the Java cache, by associating it with a session and a database. The given transient object must have an associated LOID. A transient object can acquire a LOID in two ways:

    A persistent object can become transient, retaining its persistent identity. This can occur explicitly through the makeTransient() method, or implicitly by serializing and deserializing a persistent object.

    Constants.DIRTY_STATE - Immediately mark the object as "dirty." Therefore the object will be written to the database with other dirty objects (usually when the transaction commits). A WLOCK will be placed on the object. An object with the given LOID must already exist in the database.

    Constants.CLEAN_STATE - The object becomes persistent in the "clean" state. A default lock (typically RLOCK) will be placed on the object. An object with the given LOID must already exist in the database.

    Constants.INACTIVE_STATE - The object becomes persistent in the "inactive" state. Therefore any values stored in the fields of the transient object will be discarded after setPersistentState() is called, and any access to the object will cause its fields to be fetched from the database. An object with the given LOID must not already exist in the database.

    See Also:
    and getOid

    getCachedObjects

    public java.util.Enumeration getCachedObjects(int state)
    Get an Enumerator for cached, dirty, new, deleted, clean or inactive objects.

    Parameters:
    state - The state of the cached object.

    Transparent binding makes use of a cache to cache objects that were accessed previously in a transaction. Caching prevents repeated database access for reading or writing, thereby providing a manifold increase in application execution speed.

    The state of a cached object varies based on the way the object was used in the transaction. The state of the object could be new, clean, dirty deleted or inactive.

    The possible values for the state parameter are:

    • Constants.CACHED_NEW_OBJECTS

      The state of the object is said to be new, if it has not been retrieved from the database but has been made persistent in the current transaction.

    • Constants.CACHED_DIRTY_OBJECTS

      The state of a cached object is said to be dirty if the object has been modified in the current transaction.

    • Constants.CACHED_DELETED_OBJECTS

      • The state of a cached object is said to be deleted if the object has been deleted in the current transaction.

    • Constants.CACHED_CLEAN_OBJECTS

      The state of an object is said to be clean if the object in cache has not been modified or deleted and accessing individual fields of the object will not trigger a database read. (Note: A cached object being clean does not preclude it from being outdated with respect to the object in the database).

    • Constants.CACHED_INACTIVE_OBJECTS

      • The state of a cached object is said to be inactive if the object has not been read previously and is not in the deleted or dirty states. Accessing any field in the inactive object for the first time triggers a database read. Typically objects transition to the inactive state after a commit operation. However operations such as commitAndRetain and checkPointCommit which commit and explicitly retain object state do not cause this transition.

    • Constants.CACHED_OBJECTS

      • This state is used to get a count of all cached objects.

    Returns:
    returns an Enumeration to iterate over clean, dirty, new, deleted or inactive objects. The objects contained in the Enumeration are based on the state specified matching with the actual state of the cached object.

    The following code snippet demonstrates how to iterate over some cached objects. In this particular example, the objects that have been modified in the current transaction are being printed. 

     
TransSession s = new TransSession("dbName");
Enumeration enum  = s.getCachedObjects(Constants.CACHED_DIRTY_OBJECTS);
System.out.println ("The following objects have been modified in the
                     current transaction");
while(enum.hasMoreElements()) 
    System.out.println (enum.nextElement ());

    getCachedObjectsCount

    public int getCachedObjectsCount(int state)
    Get a count of cached, dirty, new, deleted, clean or inactive objects.

    Parameters:
    state - The state of the cached object.

    Transparent binding makes use of a cache to cache objects that were accessed previously in a transaction. Caching prevents repeated database access for reading or writing, thereby providing a manifold increase in application execution speed.

    The state of a cached object varies based on the way the object was used in the transaction. The state of the object could be new, clean, dirty deleted or inactive.

    The possible values for the state parameter are:

    • Constants.CACHED_NEW_OBJECTS

      The state of the object is said to be new, if it has not been retrieved from the database but has been made persistent in the current transaction.

    • Constants.CACHED_DIRTY_OBJECTS

      The state of a cached object is said to be dirty if the object has been modified in the current transaction.

    • Constants.CACHED_DELETED_OBJECTS

      • The state of a cached object is said to be deleted if the object has been deleted in the current transaction.

    • Constants.CACHED_CLEAN_OBJECTS

      The state of an object is said to be clean if the object in cache has not been modified or deleted and accessing individual fields of the object will not trigger a database read. (Note: A cached object being clean does not preclude it from being outdated with respect to the object in the database).

    • Constants.CACHED_INACTIVE_OBJECTS

      • The state of a cached object is said to be inactive if the object has not been read previously and is not in the deleted or dirty states. Accessing any field in the inactive object for the first time triggers a database read. Typically objects transition to the inactive state after a commit operation. However operations such as commitAndRetain and checkPointCommit which commit and explicitly retain object state do not cause this transition.

    • Constants.CACHED_OBJECTS

      • This state is used to get a count of all cached objects.

    Returns:
    returns an integer count for clean, dirty, new, deleted or inactive objects. The object count is based on the state specified matching with the actual state of the cached object.

    The following code snippet demonstrates how to get the count of cached dirty objects. In this particular example, the objects that have been modified in the current transaction are being printed. 

     
TransSession s = new TransSession("dbName");
int object_count  = s.getCachedObjectsCount(Constants.CACHED_DIRTY_OBJECTS);
System.out.println ("The number of  objects modified in the
                     current transaction are :  " + object_count);
